Definite integration

When dealing with definite integrals the relevant formula is as follows:

Key Point

Integration by Parts for Definite Integrals

For definite integrals, given functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\): \[{\displaystyle\int_a^b f \cdot g \, \mathrm{d}x} = \left[f \cdot {\displaystyle\int g \, \mathrm{d}x}\right]_a^b - {\displaystyle\int_a^b \left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} \displaystyle\int g \, \mathrm{d}x \right) \, \mathrm{d}x}\]

Alternatively, given functions \(u\) and \(v\): \[{\displaystyle \int_a^b u\dfrac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} x} \,\mathrm{d}x = \left[u \cdot v\right]_a^b-\displaystyle \int_a^b v\dfrac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x} \, \mathrm{d}x}\]

Example

Find \({\displaystyle\int_0^2 x e^x \, \mathrm{d}x}\)

Solution

We let \(f = x\) and \(g = e^x\).

Then \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} = 1\) and \({\displaystyle\int g \, \mathrm{d}x} = e^x\).

Using integration by parts we obtain: \[\begin{aligned}\int_0^2 x e^x \, \mathrm{d}x &= \left[x e^x\right]_0^2 - \int_0^2 1 \cdot e^x \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= 2 e^2 - \left[e^x\right]_0^2 \\ &= 2 e^2 - [e^2 - 1] = e^2 +1 \end{aligned}\]

(or \(8.389\) to 3 d.p.)

Sometimes it is necessary to apply the formula more than once as the next Example shows.

Example

Find \({\displaystyle\int_0^2 x^2 e^x \, \mathrm{d}x}\)

Solution

We let \(f = x^2\) and \(g = e^x\).

Then \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} = 2x\) and \({\displaystyle\int g \, \mathrm{d}x} = e^x\).

Using integration by parts we obtain: \[\begin{aligned}\int_0^2 x^2 e^x \, \mathrm{d}x &= \left[x^2 e^x\right]_0^2 - \int_0^2 2x e^x \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= 4e^2 - 2\int_0^2 x e^x \, \mathrm{d}x \end{aligned}\]

The remaining integral must be integrated by parts also but we have just done this in the example above. So \[ \int_0^2 x^2 e^x \, \mathrm{d}x = 4e^2- 2[e^2+1] = 2e^2-2 \]

(or \(12.778\) to 3 d.p.)
